comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: In this photograph Lance Corporal Arthur James Bartlett is holding a Lee Enfield Mk 1 .303" rifle, known as the "Long Lee", which first entered British Service in 1895 and was still being used by battalions going to France in 1915.  Corporal Bartlett is wearing an infantry qualification badge on his right cuff, a star, which (I think) shows him to be a First Class Shot.  He is also wearing 1908 pattern webbing equipment as opposed to the leather equipment issued from 1914.  The 'sock' is simply a customised protection to prevent mud getting into the breech & bolt mechanism or the rifle magazine.  The rifle may of course be a photographer's 'prop', but the 'sock' and tunnel foresight suggest that this is Corporal Bartlett's personal weapon.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Corporal Arthur James Bartlett originally enlisted with the 2/7th Middlesex Regiment as Private 2127 A J Bartlett.  He was one of 459 men subsequently transferred to 5th Battalion London's (London Rifle Brigade) in 1916 after heavy losses opposite Gommecourt on the Somme.  Cpl Bartlett was firstly No 10650 and latterly, when the Battalion re-numbered, No 304097, (the CWGC records him as No 304097).//
